Dialogue.Page: Hello, are you here to see the experiment as well? (I hope you have “Freeze time while talking to others” on, we don’t have long.)

DialogueOption.Text: What? How are you alive? Why are we speaking the same language?
You need to stop the lava!
Good luck with your experiment, I guess?

Dialogue.Page: This is exciting, the lava is rising, and soon we will discover a great truth of nature.

DialogueOption.Text: What? How are you alive? Why are we speaking the same language?
You need to stop the lava!
The sun is going to explode, soon.
I know how to get to the Eye of the Universe!
Good luck with your experiment, I guess?

Dialogue.Page: My people have devised a way to measure the most fundamental property of the universe, its consistency. That is to say, how much sense the universe makes.
That value has held at a constant 63% throughout our history. But recently, for reasons we don’t and likely can’t understand, that value dropped to just 17%.
This sudden change opened up so many new potential avenues for research, so I’ve decided to use it to test an old hypothesis of mine.

DialogueOption.Text: Couldn’t you use that to find the Eye of the Universe instead?

Dialogue.Page: We don’t know! There is so much to discover about our newly-unstable reality.
Probably. Actually definitely, maybe. But I wanted to do the lava experiment, instead.
Long ago, I posited that there can exist too much lava. And now, we are finally going to find out.
Thatch fears the truth, only wanting to test the null hypothesis, but how could we hope to discover anything without taking some risks?

DialogueOption.Text: Aren’t you going to die in the lava too?
Isn’t that going to destroy the whole solar system?

Dialogue.Page: Of course not. I’ve planned for that in my procedure.
The step after “Fill the solar system with lava” is “Don’t die.” So I’ll be fine.
Yes, for science! For discovery’s sake, we are compelled to fill the solar system with lava!
Stop it? It’s too late for that, the experiment started several minutes ago.
And beyond that, if I stopped it, we would never learn if there is a limit to how much lava is acceptable.
That is bad, it will interfere with the experiment! Hopefully we can collect enough data before that happens.
What? I can’t hear you over the sound of discovery! (And the volcano.)
Thank you! But this is not a matter of luck. Whether my hypothesis is correct or not, we will discover the truth.
